newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Canada, France, Norway, U.S. lead ranks of states.
newsitem.headline: Canada, France, Norway, U.S. lead ranks of states.

text.p: Canada, France, Norway and the United States have the highest quality of life, according to the U.N. Human Development Index released on Thursday.

The index, published by the U.N. Development Program, sought ways of measuring living standards according to per capita income, life expectancy and educational standards. This year's report used 1994 figures.

In general the statistics showed that rich countries offer a better standard of living, even to those people who are least well off, than do poor countries. But on the other hand the report, published annually, said a high per capita income does not necessarily raise the quality of life among the population.

This year UNDP also created a separate poverty index among selected countries, attempting to compare different levels of poverty in selected countries, an exercise bound to be criticized by statisticians.
Poverty, it says, has worsened in Australia, Belgium, Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, Britain and the United States while it has decreased in Canada, Denmark, France, Italy and Spain.

The United States, for example, has one of the world's highest per capita incomes of $26,397. But the report said the number of people living in poverty is gradually rising, from 16 percent in 1974 to more than 19 percent in 1994.

It also has a short lifespan by the standards of the industrialized world of 76.2 years, in 22nd place. Japan tops the life-expectancy charts with a 79.8 average. And about 12 out of every 100,000 women die giving birth in the United States each year, double the number of Canada and Norway.

In the developing world, the report argued that most analyses have overlooked "human poverty," defined as a short life-span, illiteracy and the lack of basic services, which affect a third of the world's peoples.

But the report said there is no automatic link between income and "human poverty" and "income poverty." Latin America and the Caribbean have reduced "human poverty" to about 15 percent compared to an "income poverty" of 24 percent.
Among developing countries, the poverty index is to show deprivation of health care, education, safe water and the percentage of malnourished children.
Doing best are Trinidad and Tobago, Cuba, Chile, Singapore and Costa Rica. At the bottom of the list are Niger, Sierra Leone, Burkina Faso, Ethiopia, Mali, Cambodia and Mozambique.
